jinngine.util
Interface ComponentGraph<T,U,V>

Type Parameters:
T - Type that stores in nodes
U - Type that stores in edges
V - Type that stores in components
All Known Implementing Classes:
HashMapComponentGraph
public interface ComponentGraph<T,U,V>

An undirected graph that keeps track of connected components (groups). Each time an edge is added or removed from the graph, data structures are maintained, reflecting connected components in the graph. This means, that adding edges are roughly an O(k) operation, while removing an edge could i result in a total traversal of the graph, visiting all present edges, worst case O((n-1)^2) where n is the number of nodes. Usually this will be much cheaper, given that the graph has a low density, and is fragmented into separated components.

Method Detail

addNode

void addNode(T node)
Add a node to the graph. If the node already exists in the graph, the call will have no effect.

Parameters:
node -

removeNode

void removeNode(T node)
Remove a node from the graph. All edges incident to this node will be removed as well.

Parameters:
node -

addEdge

void addEdge(Pair<T> pair,
             U edgeelement)
Add an edge to the graph, and implicitly add included end-nodes if not already present in the graph. This is roughly an O(k) and sometimes O(nodes) operation, depending on whether components are to be merged or not.

Parameters:
pair - A pair of nodes, where an edge is to be added between them.
edgeelement - An element of type U to store in the new edge

removeEdge

boolean removeEdge(Pair<T> pair)
Remove an edge. If the removal results in one or more isolated nodes, these will be removed from the graph implicitly. For non-dense and relatively fragmented graphs, this operation will be cheap. Otherwise, for dense and strongly connected graphs, the operation could include a full traversal of the graph visiting all present edges, resulting in an O((n-1)^2) operation, where n is the number of nodes in the graph.

Parameters:
pair - edge to be removed
Returns:
true if the edge was actually removed, false if the edge did not exists before call.

getEdge

U getEdge(Pair<T> pair)
Get the edge element of type U that is stored in the edge defined by a pair of node types T. If no such edge exist, the return value is null.

Parameters:
pair - A pair of T type objects defining an edge in the graph
Returns:
The U type object stored in the edge. Return value is null if no such edge is present in the graph

getEdgesInComponent

java.util.Iterator<U> getEdgesInComponent(V c)
Return an iterator yielding the edges in the specified component.

Parameters:
c - Component to iterate
Returns:
Iterator giving the edge elements in the component

getNodesInComponent

java.util.Iterator<T> getNodesInComponent(V c)
Returns an iterator yielding the nodes present in the given component

Parameters:
c - Any component of this graph
Returns:
An iterator yielding the nodes present in the component c

getNumberOfFreeNodes

int getNumberOfFreeNodes()
Return the number of free nodes, which are nodes that are not a part of a graph component

getFreeNodes

java.util.Iterator<T> getFreeNodes()
Get all free nodes. A free node is not in any component.

getConnectedNodes

java.util.Iterator<T> getConnectedNodes(T node)
Get all nodes that is connected to the given node. The constructible pairs Pair can then be used to obtain the edge type U using getEdge(Pair)
